3861618870.resolved_title: Our Pungent History: Sweat, Perfume, and the Scent of Death
3861618870.excerpt: Over the last few millennia, as scientific knowledge and social norms have fluctuated, what Westerners considered smelling “good“ has changed drastically.

2.caption:
Top: A Mum deodorant advertisement from the 1920s captures the beginning
 of the modern deodorized era. Above: This Egyptian relief carving 
illustrates the making of lily perfume, circa 2500 B.C. Via Wikimedia.

3.caption: A Roman perfume flask made from banded agate, circa late 1st century B.C.–early 1st century A.D. Via the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

4.caption:
John Singer Sargent painted the Moroccan-inspired “Fumee d’Ambre Gris,” 
or “Smoke of Ambergris,” in 1880, long after the substance had become 
popular in the West for its aromatic qualities. Via the Clark.

5.caption:
Left, a 17th-century jar inscribed with “Mesue’s French Musked Lozenges 
of Aloes Wood”

6.caption:
This woodcut engraving from the mid-16th century depicts the process of 
distilling essential oils from plants with a conical condenser. Via the Wellcome Library, London.

7.caption: The distinctive beaked mask worn by plague doctors was filled with aromatic substances supposed to prevent them from catching the illness, as seen in this illustration, circa 1656. Via Wikimedia.

8.caption: A tiny, ornately decorated scent bottle meant for carrying on a chain, circa 16th century. Via the Museum of London.

9.caption: This spherical pomander opens into separate compartments for different scents, circa early 17th century. Via the Victoria & Albert Museum.

10.caption: An agate-topped silver vinaigrette with an engraved interior grill, circa 1857.

11.caption: This 1866 political cartoon by George John Pinwell plays on epidemiologist John Snow’s work linking London cholera outbreaks to contaminated water.

12.caption: Perfume was positioned as a feminine cosmetic by the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries, as seen in this 1901 advertisement for Parfumerie Violet by Louis Théophile Hingre.

13.caption: Antiseptics like Listerine caught on as a way to prevent infection, but were eventually applied to specific areas of the human body, including the mouth, armpit, and genitals. The ad above is from 1917.

14.caption: In 1928, “A Tale of Soap and Water” spread the good word of the soap and glycerine industry to schoolchildren via illustrations like this.

15.caption: American marketers played on insecurities to make deodorant a must-have product, like with this Odo-Ro-No ad from 1939.

16.caption: During the 20th century, deodorant companies marketed many damaging products as healthy, like the spray seen in this 1969 ad.

17.caption: This post originally appeared on Collectors Weekly and was published March 8, 2016. This article is republished here with permission.Interested in getting your own collector’s items appraised from experts and professionals?Value my stuff

4012440228.given_title: Scents of Self: Why Young Chinese are Obsessed with Fragrances
4012440228.resolved_title: Scents of Self: Why Young Chinese are Obsessed with Fragrances
4012440228.excerpt: In 2020, during her sophomore year at university, Zhang Qijing was so captivated by the sweet scent of osmanthus blossoms wafting across campus that she went out and purchased her first perfume. Little did she know where that bottle would lead her.
